Introduction
Daniel R Brooks is professor emeritus, Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of Toronto. Daniel does research in the evolutionary biology of climate change and emerging disease (project The Stockholm Paradigm: testing the elements of a paradigm in evolution using theoretical and empirical data) and using foundations of evolutionary theory in coping with the challenges of climate change.

Projects

Projects (5)
The Major Metaphors of Evolution: Putting Evolution to Work for Humanity in a Time of Crisis
Project
Current mainstream evolutionary theory is flawed. In the 160 years since Darwin, the theory has been highly modified into an overly simplified version of the original, focused almost entirely on the incorrect notion of “survival of the fittest” producing organisms that are “perfectly adapted” to their environments. This kind of thinking perpetuates a view that the biosphere is highly fragile, when in fact it is robust, full of potential, and highly resilient to change. To persist indefinitely in a changing world, being fit (surviving and reproducing) is all that is required, not being the fittest. Understanding this seemingly subtle difference in what Darwin said — “survival of the fit” — versus what evolutionary theory became — “survival of the fittest” — has some profound implications for how we view the biosphere and its ability to cope with change.
